During the Six-Day War, he commands troops on the Egyptian front.
The Yom Kippur War begins and Sharon is called out of retirement as head of the Army's Armored Reserve Division.
Resigns from the Knesset to return to the army.

A report is released about Israel's role in the September 1982 Sabra and Shatilla refugee camp massacres in Lebanon, finding Sharon indirectly responsible for the events because his forces did not stop the Christian Phalangist militia group, which carried out the murders of hundreds of Arabs.
This report is the impetus for Sharon's resignation as defense minister.
Is elected head of Israel's Likud party.
Wins a special election for prime minister.
Orders air strikes against Palestinian security installations in his first significant military action since assuming office.
Sharon and Yasser Arafat approve a timeline for bringing a halt to Israeli-Palestinian violence and resuming peace talks.
Defying Sharon, the Likud Party votes in favor of a resolution to never allow the creation of a Palestinian state.
All six ministers in Sharon's cabinet belonging to the Israeli Labor Party resign.
Labor Party members of the Knesset vote against Sharon's 2003 budget.
Defeats Foreign Minister Benjamin Netanyahu for control of the Likud party in a primary election.
Is re-elected to his second term as prime minister.
Sharon meets face to face with the newly elected Prime Minister of Palestine, Mahmoud Abbas.
Abbas, US President George W. Bush, Jordanian King Abdullah II and Sharon discuss the Middle East "road map" in Aqaba, Jordan.
Plans are announced for Mahmoud Abbas and Sharon to meet.
Resigns from the right-wing Likud party.
Registers his new political party under the name Kadima, Hebrew for "Forward."
Suffers a minor stroke.
Is admitted to Hadassah University Hospital in Jerusalem after suffering a significant stroke and is under anesthesia and on a respirator.
Doctors remove approximately 20 inches of intestine after a lack of blood flow had caused the area to become gangrenous.
Sharon remains comatose and in critical but stable condition.
The Israeli cabinet declares Sharon permanently incapacitated, formally ending his term as prime minister.
Is transferred from Hadassah Hospital to a long-term care facility, Tel HaShomer Hospital in Tel Aviv.
Is transferred to the intensive care unit of Sheba Hospital.
Tests show "significant brain activity," where Sharon's brain appeared to respond when doctors showed him pictures of his family and had him listen to his son's voice.
Sharon dies after eight years in a coma, according to Israeli Army Radio.
Sharon was 85.
